title.value: Synergies between Disentanglement and Sparsity: Generalization and Identifiability in Multi-Task Learning
title.justification: The name of the paper as stated in the provided text
title.quote: Synergies between Disentanglement and Sparsity: Generalization and Identifiability in Multi-Task Learning

extractions.description: This paper explores the connections between disentangled representations and sparse task-specific predictors in improving generalization and identifiability in multi-task learning. The authors provide theoretical insights and propose a bi-level optimization framework to learn disentangled representations. They validate their theoretical findings with empirical results on few-shot learning benchmarks.

type.justification: The paper includes both theoretical insights and empirical validation through experiments.
type.quote: Finally, we draw a connection between this bi-level optimization problem and formulations from the meta-learning literature. Inspired by our identifiability result, we enhance an existing method (Lee et al., 2019), where the task-specific predictors are now group-sparse SVMs. We show that this new meta-learning algorithm achieves competitive performance on the miniImageNet benchmark (Vinyals et al., 2016), while only using a fraction of the representation.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on improving multi-task learning through disentanglement and sparsity.
name.quote: In this work, we explore synergies between disentanglement and sparse task-specific predictors in the context of multi-task learning.

name.justification: The work discusses learning disentangled representations, which is a core area within representation learning.
name.quote: In this section, we first provide a new identification result (Theorem 3.1, Section 3.2), which states that in the multi-task learning setting, regularizing the task-specific predictors to be sparse can yield disentangled representations.

name.justification: The experimental validations include applications in meta-learning scenarios.
name.quote: We explore a meta-learning version of this algorithm based on group Lasso multiclass SVM predictors, for which we derive a tractable dual formulation.

name.justification: The experimental part includes benchmarks standard in few-shot learning tasks.
name.quote: It obtains competitive results on standard few-shot classification benchmarks, while each task is using only a fraction of the learned representations.

name.justification: The few-shot learning experiments were conducted on the miniImageNet dataset.
name.quote: We show that this new meta-learning algorithm achieves competitive performance on the miniImageNet benchmark (Vinyals et al., 2016), while only using a fraction of the representation.
